awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Physics of Stellar Feedback and Star Formation Regulation in Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will study why stars form so slowly and inefficiently in galaxies.  They will model key "feedback" effects, like how young stars blast their surroundings with intense light.  The team will add the models to new simulations of how stars form.  These simulations will have much more realism than prior ones.  Senior team members will mentor junior members.  The latter will include undergraduates from universities in Puerto Rico and Hispanic-serving universities in California.  The team will showcase their research at science museums in Puerto Rico and in high school classrooms in the Chicago area.
 
The team will investigate how stellar feedback operates and how it regulates star formation in galaxies.  Their goals are to (1) reveal how interstellar turbulence and galactic winds are generated; (2) investigate the effects of time-dependent molecular chemistry on the interstellar medium, star formation, and outflows; (3) quantify the effects of self-consistent radiation-hydrodynamics on radiative feedback and observational tracers; (4) study the effects of magnetic fields and cosmic rays on the interstellar medium and galactic winds; (5) synthesize the results into a generalized analytic theory of star formation regulation and outflows; (6) develop new, more predictive sub-grid models to capture these processes in fully cosmological galaxy evolution models; and (7) release mock data products for comparison with current and future observations.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER award enabled significant strides in advancing our understanding of star formation and stellar feedback, such as the energy output by supernovae, in galaxies. The project involved developing sophisticated computational simulations to systematically explore how stellar feedback regulates star formation. These simulations, increasing in complexity, have provided novel insights into the generation of interstellar turbulence and galactic winds, crucial elements in galaxy evolution. The project investigated the effects of physical processes typically neglected in previous theoretical studies, including radiation, magnetic fields, cosmic rays, and time-dependent interstellar chemistry. This comprehensive approach informed the development of mathematical models of star formation, enhancing our understanding of galaxy formation and improving the predictive power of galaxy simulations.

Beyond these scientific achievements, the project had substantial educational and societal impacts. The development of the Firefly visualization tool exemplified the project's commitment to making science accessible and engaging. This tool has been a cornerstone in educational initiatives, helping demystify complex astrophysical concepts for students and the public. The project's focus on community outreach, through various programs and public lectures, further extended the reach of the award, sparking interest and curiosity across diverse audiences.

Additionally, the project played a major role in the professional development of emerging scientists. Students (ranging from high school to graduate students) and postdocs involved in the project gained hands-on experience in advanced research methodologies, data analysis, and effective scientific communication. These opportunities enhanced their academic achievements and prepared them for future challenges in their careers, in academia or beyond. Overall, this CAREER award not only advanced our scientific understanding of star formation in galaxies but will also have a lasting impact on education, community engagement, and the nurturing of the next generation of astrophysicists.
